characters: BACK TO HOWIE OUTSIDE GABBY'S HOUSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of an upscale suburban community. Boats on the water. A quiet street. A picket gate. EXT. BACK YARD OF A BEAUTIFUL HOME - LARCHMONT, NY — MORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gorgeous spring day, and we move in on an impeccab laid out garden. Straight rows of flowers in full bloom, manicured bushes, and a trellis with climbing vines. BECCA CORBETT, attractive, 30's, walks into frame draggin heavy bag of potting soil. She pulls the soil bag over to section of the garden where she had been digging, and cut the bag open. Becca dumps the soil onto the ground where she is plantin flowers. Behind her, we see part of her fine house and across the street, a shimmering stretch of water. Becca is on her knees now mixing potting soil with earth. She starts to plant a straight line of young plants as a border to her flower-bed. She picks up the hose from beside the free-standing garag Near her we notice an empty doghouse A little later, Becca stands with a hose, watering the garden. She admires her day's work.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Becca? Becca turns to see her neighbor PEG, middle-aged, peeking from behind the gate leading to the next property. She co into the garden. Becca is a little uncomfortable, but alw polite.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh...Hey Peg.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: It looks so nice back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I’m just, you know, trying to get things back into shape.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: Listen, I don’t know if you and Howie are free tonight, but we’re having a few people over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s very sweet of you.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: I know it’s really short notice.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Actually, we have plans.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: (beat) Oh. Oh, well.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: But, uh, another time though. I haven't talked to Pete in ages.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: Well you haven’t missed much. He’s still the same S.0.B. he always was. Peg chuckles. Becca looks down to see that Peg has steppe on a plant recently put in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: Oh God. I’m so sorry. (steps off the plant)

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: These stupid feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, have a great dinner, Peg. This is her gentle cue to leave, and Peg gets the hint. S backs out of the yard politely.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: We'll do it next time.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Absolutely. But they both know this is probably a lie.

dialogues.speaker: PEG
dialogues.text: Say hi to Howie for me.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I sure will. Becca closes the gate after Peg. As soon as she's gone, Becca moves over to tend to the crushed plant. She assesses the damage, and sighs, peeved INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN —- EARLY EVENING Becca stands at her sink, rinsing vegetables in a colande Across the way, she can see right into her neighbor's liv room, where Peg, PETE and their guests are chatting. Peg’s in the midst of a very animated story that has ever laughing hysterically. Becca watches for a moment, then turns off the water in the sink, dries her hands, and tur the blinds so no one can see inside. Howie, home from work, comes in and grabs a beer.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Smells good in there.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: If Peg asks, we went out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Where'd we go?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We saw the Stoppard play.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Did we enjoy it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Very much. Becca is at the stove now melting some butter in a pan.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: She asked us to dinner again.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: She's just being nice.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You're more than welcome to go over there.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: And abandon your risotto? (wraps arms around her)

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Careful, Howie. The pan’s hot. She pushes him off gently, and continues stirring the pot She’s all business tonight. Howie watches for a moment, then takes a bite of some of food being cooked.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (gently scolding) Hey...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey... (heads out) I’m gonna hop in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. About twenty minutes. INT. BECCA'S LIVING ROOM —- NIGHT A beautiful room. Becca sits on the couch reading. It's late. The house is quiet. We hear only a ticking clock. Then the phone rings, startling Becca. She doesn't move get it. She just stares at it, afraid to answer it. Finally she reaches over, and picks it up...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hello? Becca listens. The news is not good. She’s confused.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is pulling on her jacket when Howie comes downstair sleepy, in gym shorts and a t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca and her sister IZZY, early 30's, are walking down t steps and back to the car. Becca is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You have nothing to say?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (beat - confused) Thank you? This is not what Becca meant.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You were in a bar-fight.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It wasn't a bar-fight.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You were in a bar. Fighting.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a fight. Some drunk girl was screaming in my face, so I hit her and that was the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well who was she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: People don’t scream at you for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Sure they do, you should get out more.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: God Izzy, it’s so...Jerry Springer.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean? You think I’m trashy?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You can’t keep doing this. You’re not a kid anymore.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know there was a cutoff date.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well there is. For acting like a jackass, there’s a cutoff date... Becca unlocks her car as they approach - BLOOP-BLOOP.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I wanna stop worrying about you.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Hey, don't worry about me. She was the one on the floor. Becca and Izzy in the car.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Can I stay with you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One light turns on in a downstairs room.  UPSTAIRS HALLWAY — A MOMENT LATER Becca sneaks out of her bedroom. She hears voices, and th distinct sound of a little boy laughing. She takes a moment, then steels herself and heads downstairs silently LIVING ROOM — CONTINUOUS Becca finds Howie, seated with the lights off, watching a video of Danny on his phone. He doesn’t notice her presen HOWIE (on video) Now, Danny, I wanna tell you a secret, ‘kay? When you go back down, give Mom a big kiss, okay? Ready?... One, two, three. ...Oh, that was high! Whoo! Howie smiles as he watches the video. He is smiling. HOWIE (on video) Danny, look at me when you come back. BECCA (on video) He’s getting used to it. HOWIE (on video) Do you want any cake? DANNY (on video) Yeah! HOWIE (on video) Oh, do we have cake today? BECCA (on video) Yeah, we do. DANNY (on video) Yeah. HOWIE (on video) Oh, my gosh. And you really want some? This is too hard for Becca. She backs away as the video continues, and sneaks back up the stairs, unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand reaches into frame and draws a straight line in bl ink. The hand draws a parallel black line and then connec the two with an oddly shaped circular end. We pull back to reveal the hand is drawing a network of intersecting tubes and portal openings. The artist shades a section. INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN - THE NEXT DAY — MORNING Becca is putting some finishing touches on a creme brulee that she has just prepared in her kitchen. Her eyes narro in concentration as she carefully cauterizes the top of i into a brown hard shell. Izzy stands nearby in her bathrobe, waiting expectantly. Howie enters the kitchen with his gym bag.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn’t Ma Barker.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I’m sure that would be very funny if I knew who that was.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Rick and I are gonna play squash. (kisses Becca goodbye) I have my cell if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Squash. You go play squash, Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You don’t even know what squash is.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I don’t care what squash is Izzy's cell phone rings. She checks the called I.D., and smiles while answering the phone.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? (heads out of the room) Yeah! Yeah. (laughs) I thought she was gonna kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Izzy paces around the room while chatting on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Yeah, I know. I think Auggie must have told her. Izzy sees Becca enter the room holding up the créme brule

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hey, I gotta go. Izzy hang up the phone and excitedly takes the creme brul from Becca.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Mmm. Thank you Becca. Izzy takes a seat by the window, and starts tapping the caramel with the spoon.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Oo, I like the way it cracks.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Becca watches her eat for a couple moments. Then...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So you did know that woman.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (throws her head back) Oh my god! Why are you listening to my phone conversations?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping with that girl's boyfriend. Izzy eats, really wanting to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It’s been over between them. They’re just living together because of the rent.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Then why did she accost you?  10.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Because she's a lunatic! (beat) And Auggie told her I was pregnant. Becca lets out a disapproving chuckle. But Izzy isn’t joking. Slowly...Becca realizes.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You are not.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna love him. He's a really great guy. He’s a musician!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: He works, Becca. He gets work as a musician.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: How long have you known?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: A few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Did you tell Mom? Izzy nods sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. You told Mom before me?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Why do you think? This just sits there for a couple beats.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Becca. I know the timing really sucks.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hey, what can ya do? Becca has been disarmed. How to proceed? Luckily, she’s a really good liar...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’m just glad you finally told me. They hug. Becca is obviously still processing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie and his best friend, RICK, athletic, 30's, are in t midst of an intense game of squash. It's all grunts and thwacks and squeaking sneakers. Howie loses the point. INT. LOCKER ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Sweaty and spent, the men enter chatting. Their banter is easy and mostly good-natured.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Debbie’s been driving me crazy with these kitchen renovations. The counter-top negotiations alone...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I told you not to marry an agent. They open their lockers and get changed over the followin

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: She still hasn't called, you know.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (beat - guilt) No, I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to be a pest about it, but... I just know Becca would love to hear from her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I know. I tell her, Howie. I do. But she’s still...I don’t know freaked out, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It’s been eight months.  12.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I know. I'll talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (changing) Hey, how are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: They’re good. Emily's doing ballet. Robby is in tee-ball.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Wow. Tee-ball. Howie tries to look interested, but Rick sees through it.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (tries to sound off-hand) Have you guys talked at all about having another?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (beat) No. (beat) It's a little soon. Rick nods. They go back to changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca and Howie talk quietly as they walk into the meetin room.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Just be open-minded. That’s all I’m asking.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’m here, aren’t I? Couples mill about drinking coffee, waiting for the meeti to begin. Becca and Howie steel themselves as another cou approaches. GABBY is attractive. KEVIN seems tired. They both make Becca uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey.  13.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, good. Hanging in there. Howie looks to Becca, who looks a little ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, um, we just...found out that Becca’s sister is pregnant. So.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (a warning) Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: That can be hard, I remember when my cousin got pregnant--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's not really a big deal. Becca wants to end this conversation. She’s miffed Howie even brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Okay. If you wanna talk about it though, you know the group’s right here.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Yeah, I don't think so. "Hey everybody, fresh meat."

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Becca, be nice.  14.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: (to Kevin) Doesn't she remind of you of Lydia? (back to Howie and Becca) There was this woman in the group a couple years ago--

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It was four. Four years ago.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Well it doesn’t really matter when she was here, my point is that she reminds me of Lydia. She really wasn’t into the support group model at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is suddenly confused. Did she just mishear her?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (confused) How long have you been in Group?

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: It'll be eight years in June. Becca is stunned, and can barely hide it. Eight years.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn’t... I didn’t realize it was that long.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re the veterans. You know for us, it’s a good way to touch base. Everyone’s on a different schedule...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Of course. Becca is staring at Kevin. His misery is still palpable. And this terrifies her. INT. MEETING HALL — LATER THAT NIGHT The meeting is in full swing. A grieving father, SAM, is speaking to the group in a very heartfelt manner. His wif (ANA) holds his hand throughout.  15.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She, uh, she visits me sometimes. In dreams. And she tells me it’s okay. And she’s with God. He checks in with his wife. Then continues.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And we have good days. Then you think that if you have enough good days it might actually get better. But then... Several of the other parents nod with recognition. Becca, however, actually looks annoyed. She looks to Howie and rolls her eyes a little.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It was her anniversary last week.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: A year last Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And it just starts all over again. We just have to remind each other that it was just part of God’s plan. And we can’t know why. Only God can know why.

dialogues.speaker: ANA
dialogues.text: God had to take her. He needed another angel.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He needed another angel.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) Why didn’t he just make one? Silence. They all turn to Becca, confused.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Another angel. I mean, he’s God after all. Why didn’t he just make another angel? She is met with stunned silence - a mix of confusion and offense. Even Howie is taken aback by her outburst. Gabby notices Kevin smirking a little.  16.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Just putting it out there... But no one responds. Becca leaves over to Howie and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'd like to go. (to the group) I think we’re gonna go. (to Howie) Is that alright? Howie stands, stunned. He and Becca make an awkward exit.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca and Howie look through the menus, mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: They're talking, it’s their time, and you have to respect that.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I mean, you sit there for weeks and you don’t say a word.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I can’t stand the god- freaks. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: But they're not all like that. Kevin and Gabby aren't.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No. Kevin and Gabby are professional wallowers. Did you hear what they said? Eight years, Howie. Eight. If that’s what you want to become, then...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Look, if you wanna take a break--  17.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, not a break, I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I know the Izzy stuff got under your skin--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Please don't do that. One semester of Psychology fifteen years ago and suddenly you can analyze--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well Jesus, Becca--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (a little too firmly) I just don't like the group. I gave it a try, and it's not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is final. Howie knows he can’t win this argument.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s not for you.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Thank you. (back to the menu...then) Do you mind if we not eat here? Nothing's really jumping out at me. He lets out a breath - perfect - and closes the menu. INT. BECCA'S KITCHEN — THE NEXT DAY Becca is alone in the kitchen. It’s the middle of the day and the house is deadly quiet. She’s been alone with her thoughts for awhile. She stares at the paintings on the fridge. She takes them in - a tree, a robot, a shark attacking a woman. They all have the distinctive scrawl o child, and the name Danny written across the bottom. Becca looks closely for a moment, and then removes the Magnets one by one, taking the paintings off the fridge, simply and without emotion.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Becca cleans out the kitchen cabinets. Kids’ cereals, jui boxes, mac & cheese, all tossed in a garbage bag.  18. INT. DANNY'S ROOM — DAY The room looks essentially the same as it did when Danny alive. Becca is at his dresser pulling clothes out of the drawers and tossing them into a laundry basket. She doesn pause over the clothes or give them much consideration. She's just doing the laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca loads Danny's clothes into the washing machine. The water is running. She carefully fills a cup with soap pow and pours it over the laundry. She stops for a moment to watch the agitator grind away at the clothes. Then she closes the lid. INT. BECCA’S LAUNDRY ROOM — DAY Becca, holding the laundry basket, is standing, staring a the dryer. BUZZZZZZZ and the dryer cycle ends. She opens the dryer door and starts to unload. EXT. CITY STREET — YONKERS — DAY Becca drives through a less nice neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca's car pulls into the driveway of a rundown house on rundown block. She gets out of the car, and lifts a large garbage bag from the trunk. She seems to be energized and better spirits. She walks up the driveway, and is suddenly startled by TA big dog barking on the other side of the fence that leads back. Becca stiffens, her good mood gone. The dog is loud and happy. AUGGIE, a scruffy African American guy in his 30’s comes across the yard with a heaping bowl of dog food.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Taz! Stop! Come here and eat! Come on! Taz goes running to the bowl of food, and Auggie approach Becca at the fence. She’s confused. Who is this guy?  She’s not She fixes 19.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Sorry. He’s not really dangerous. (to Taz) Hey, eat. (to Becca) Just kinda dumb.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, I know. He’s my dog.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, you're Becca! Of course! I should've recognized you. I’m Auggie. sure how to take this. What has Izzy told him? a loose strand of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi, Auggie.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Auggie and Becca shakes hands. The front door opens to re NAT, Becca’s mom, plump and in her sixties.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Oh my god, why didn't you tell me you were coming over? I would've picked up the house. (indicates) That’s Auggie.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, we met. Is Izzy here?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (her eyes narrow) Oh yeah, she's here. (does not approve) She got fired from the Applebee's. Becca follows her mother into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca, chipper again, is unpacking the piles of Danny's clothes onto the table. Izzy sits watching, not exactly s what to say. She’s uneasy.  20.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I was planning to bring it all down to Goodwill, but now I'm glad I didn't. Look at all these shirts, and the sweaters. Nat buzzes around making them coffee.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I don't know, Bec. They're in baby clothes for so long, it'd be awhile before he could even fit into that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It comes up very quickly. You'll see. You’re gonna be happy I saved them. Auggie crosses through the kitchen with bagpipes.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Is he living here?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: He has to. His girlfriend kicked him out.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Ex-girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: She knew what I meant. Becca holds up a little shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Did you see this one?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Cute. But what if it's a girl?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Then I'll give them to someone else. You're gonna thank me. A couple years worth of clothes here. Think of the money you'll save.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It's not about the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it should be. You need to start thinking about that. Especially if the dad's a musician. It costs a lot to raise a child.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (finally) It'd be weird, Becca. If it's a boy. To see him running around in Danny's clothes. (beat) I would feel weird about it. The air is sucked out of the room. Becca looks down at th clothes, suddenly feeling a little stupid. Nat doesn't mo Her eyes look from one daughter to the other.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m sorry. Of course it'd be weird. I don't know what I was--

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It was a nice offer.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You’re gonna get a lot of clothes anyway - Christmas, Birthdays. You won’t have to worry about that. She's re-bagging the clothes. Nat tries to lighten the mo

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: It's probably a girl anyway. I'ma little psychic about these things. Remember I said Sheila was having a girl? And Karen? I think there's a girl in there.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I hope there is. That's what I want. I mean, either way, so long as it's healthy obviously, but I hope it's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Me too. She looks to Izzy and tries to smile supportively.  22.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You want some coffee cake, honey? I got some coffee cake in here.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna take off. I promised Howie that I'd pick up some dinner. (re: cake) Mmm looks good though. Becca lifts the bag, awkwardly. Nat and Izzy exchange loo After Becca’s gone...

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (to Izzy) Here. Eat some cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca gets out of her car, grabs the garbage bag of cloth from her trunk, and makes her way to the Goodwill drop-bo Once there, she considers what she's about to do for just moment, and then lifts the bag into the drop box. She tur on her heel and heads back to the car, without looking ba INT. BECCA'S CAR — A MOMENT LATER Becca pulls up to a stoplight, and she takes a deep breat determined to hold it together. A school bus pulls up beside her car, and Becca glances o at it. Sitting in one of the window-seats is a teenage bo facing front. Becca stares at him curiously. And then the grip on her steering wheel tightens. The boy turns his head slightly and for just a second, Be gets a good look - it's JASON WILLETTE, 17. BACK TO BECCA — CONTINUOUS Becca leans forward, trying to get a better view of the b The light changes to green and the bus takes off. Becca, shaken, just watches it go. And then the car behin her starts honking, and Becca is snapped back to reality. She puts her foot on the gas.  23. EXT. ROADS OF LARCHMONT — DAY The school bus rolls through the manicured streets of the town. It stops at a corner to let a couple students off. And then the bus continues on. When it does, Becca's car rolls into frame, keeping a saf distance from the bus she’s trailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca watches the bus drive through a YELLOW LIGHT. Her e widen with alarm. Her foot on the accelerator. Her car moves through the intersection just as the light is turni RED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus has stopped, and Becca pulls up a discreet distan behind it. This time a 14-YEAR-OLD GIRL gets off followed by...Jason, book-bag slung over his shoulder. The Girl wa off in one direction as the bus pulls away. Becca watches as Jason heads in the other direction and u the driveway of a nice house. He slips inside. Becca sits there for awhile. Then finally pulls away. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE’S LIVING ROOM — NIGHT Becca and Howie have settled onto the couch after dinner. Becca sits, lost in thought, holding an empty wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: When did Rick ever beat me in squash?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Did he mention Debbie at all?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You can call her, you know. Get the reports directly.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna call her. She should call me. Howie heads into the kitchen and tosses the empty bottle the recycling bin.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I would have been there for her if god forbid anything had ever happened to Robby or Em.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Howie stops at the fridge, and notices that Danny's paint are gone. Not sure what to make of it, he just stands the

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t have vanished the way she did.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Howie?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Howie stands in the doorway, debating whether to mention paintings or not. He decides against it.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You know what I mean? Howie grabs a remote instead and clicks on the stereo. Al Green's "Simply Beautiful" plays quietly. Becca looks up, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. He moves onto the couch to massage her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Turn around. Come on, you need to relax. Howie starts to massage Becca’s back.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You're shoulders are all knotted up.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...  25.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Forget about Debbie, and whatever else is bothering you. Howie continues to massage her. Becca seems to warm up to it. He kisses her neck. She giggles a little.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Ohhh, I see what this is. Dimming the lights.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You’re trying to seduce me. Plying me with liquor.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It worked in college.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That’s enough. Becca pushes him away playfully.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's enough. (gets up off the couch)

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'm feeling kinda antsy tonight. I’m sorry. It was a weird day--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Right. Howie clicks off the music, and lets out a grumpy sigh.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What, now you’re gonna pout?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well it's been eight months.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) But who's keeping track?  26.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Iam. I'm keeping track.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'm just not ready yet, Howie. I'm sorry if you think that's abnormal--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Then what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: We need to at least head in that direction, which might feel strange at first, but...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: But you wanna have sex.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well don't say it like that.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You’re trying to rope me into having sex!

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I am not. I wasn't roping you into sex-—

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Al Green isn't roping?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Al Green?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I thought it was nice. That's all. I was trying to make things nice.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well you can't. I'm sorry. But things aren't "nice" anymore. They're silent. Howie just stares at her.  27. LIVING ROOM — LATER THAT NIGHT Howie is seated with the lights off, watching a video of Danny on his phone. We see flashes of Danny on the little screen, spinning ar in what seems to be a tire swing. We hear a dog barking. HOWIE (on video) And, will you hold him for a second? Just hold him, just hold him like that. DANNY (on video) (laughing) Dad, quit it! BECCA (on video) (laughing) Quit it. The video is mostly a blur, with Danny’s laughing face co into focus for just a second as he swings on a tire swing

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, pull him past you. All right, now. BECCA (on video) Cause Taz wants to go on the tire. HOWIE (on video) Hold on. Hold on. Let me see Mom and-- BECCA (on video) Okay, you ready? I’m gonna let you go. Ready? DANNY (on video) Yes. BECCA (on video) Here goes. There! Whoa! Keep your feet up. HOWIE (on video) Danny, look at me on the way back. BECCA (on video) Keep your feet up, Danny. Howie continues to watch the video.  28.

dialogues.speaker: A_ BLANK BLACK PAGE
dialogues.text: The hand reaches into frame and starts to place cutouts o the earlier seen portal openings on top of each other. The hand cuts out several more portal openings and adds t to the intersecting group. We pull back to reveal a large network of intersecting tunnels. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE'S EXERCISE ROOM — MORNING Becca is working out on the elliptical, listening to her Ipod, when Howie enters the room dressed for work. She looks over at him but doesn't stop her work-out.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) If you're not gonna go to Group, I think you should see someone. (pause - no response)

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Any plans for the day?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You're looking at ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Well, I’1l see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yup. Becca never stops her workout. Howie heads upstairs.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is at the window, still winded and sweaty from her exercise, watching as Howie pulls out from his parking sp in front of the house. As soon as he drives off, she darts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is rifling through her closet looking for an outfit She pulls out a couple business suits, wrapped in plastic and looks them over. She hasn't seen these in awhile. She holds one of the suits up to herself. She looks sligh pained. Is she really going to do this?

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Showered and dressed, Becca applies a little makeup, then checks herself out in the mirror. She looks good. EXT. TRAIN STATION — A MOMENT LATER Becca, coffee and newspaper in hand, heads up to the trai platform just as the train pulls in. This all feels so familiar to her. EXT. MIDTOWN — MANHATTAN — DAY Becca walks towards us on a sidewalk. The streets are pac with people, and the sidewalks cramped with fruit stands kebab carts. Becca loves it all. Back in her element. A SHOT of the top of a sculptural Frank Gehry-like mirror building. We tilt down to find an ebullient Becca crossin the street and entering the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all glass and class in here. Becca approaches a RECEPTIONIST at the reception desk. She's all smiles and confidence.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm here to see Scott Bader in the Events Department.  The Receptionist searches her computer for the name.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I don't have a Bader listed.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Well that’s weird. 30. Her heart sinks. Not what she planned on. What to do now?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Kate Finn. What about Kate?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I have a Robert Finn in Dec. Arts? (Becca shakes her head) If you have an appointment, I can just call up there. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (on the ropes a bit) Um...I’m just...I didn’t have an appointment actually. I'm just an old friend. I used to work here. She eyes her. She doesn’t remember her.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Becca? She turns to see a youngish guy in a suit, GARY, standing there with a Starbucks tray of several coffees. Former fr boy type. Becca doesn't recognize him at first, but then.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Gary?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Heeey. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Um...I had some errands in the city, and thought I'd pop in and say hello. But apparently nobody works here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, Scott went over to Christie's back in March. The traitor.  31.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well nice to see you’re still doing the coffee runs at least.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I don’t usually-- Um, I’m in Scott’s old job. Becca is clearly surprised, and a little confused. The lobby seems to be filled with people younger and bett dressed than Becca is. Being here suddenly feels like a b mistake. Becca fights the impulse to run for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hey, how's the family?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You know what, Gary? I know how busy it gets up there, so I’m gonna let you get back to it.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Yeah, that hasn't changed.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It was great to see you though.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you too. And she takes off. In her haste, she nearly gets taken ou by the revolving door. She waits for the next opening, an makes her exit. Gary just stands with the coffees in the middle of the lo watching her go. That was weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca hurries down the street, shaken up, and eager to ge back home. Coming here was a terrible idea. EXT. SUBURBAN STREET — LARCHMONT - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca drives with a purpose. She checks the time on her watch. If she hurries she can still make it.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is in her car, back in her spot, parked a safe dist from Jason’s house. Finally the school bus pulls up the hill. Becca slumps do in her seat so as not to be seen. The bus pulls over. Becca peeks up over the steering whee and watches as Jason gets off followed by the 14-year-old Girl. She walks off while Jason pauses on the sidewalk to adjust his backpack. The bus pulls away. But instead of heading to his house, Jason walks toward Becca.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Shit. Panicked, she grabs a baseball cap from the backseat and quickly puts it on. Jason, meanwhile, doesn't even notice her. He walks right past the car, and down the street. Becca looks up tentatively, and watches in the rearview mirror as Jason disappears around the corner. Becca starts the car, pulls away, and bangs a U-Turn, dri back in the direction Jason is headed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca trails him in the car, keeping a safe distance. EXT. LARCHMONT AVENUE — MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca slows as she sees him head towards the entrance of public library. She turns to park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is returning a book to an elderly LIBRARIAN.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Well there are fines you know.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, I know.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: The book’s quite overdue. We've sent out several notices.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Seven dollars. Becca spies all this from behind a row of bookcases, pretending to browse the stacks. She watches as Jason pays the late fee. The librarian tak the money, and heads into a back room. Jason, meanwhile, heads off into another part of the library. When the coast is clear Becca approaches the front desk. She looks down at the book Jason returned - "Parallel Universes" by Fred Alan Wolf. Pretty dry stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Becca looks up to find the librarian back at her station.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Uh, yes, actually. Would it be possible for me to check this out? Becca smiles at the librarian.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is heading for the exit with the book, when somethi stops her. In the children's section a young mom, ABBY, i reading "The Runaway Bunny" to her little girl, LILLY, 3.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: "I will become a fish in a trout stream and I will swim away from you.” Look he’s--  34.

dialogues.speaker: LILLY
dialogues.text: He's in the water.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Yes, he is, "If you become a fish in the trout stream, said his mother, I will become a fisherman and I will fish for you." Becca turns away abruptly and makes for the exit. But not before she smacks straight into Jason.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh! Sorry. Then she sees it's him. They both stand there, stunned, a little terrified. It's as if time has stopped for a momen Jason sees the Parallel Universes book in her arm and loo as if he's about to speak, when Becca turns and hurries o of the library. He just watches her go, shaken. INT. HOWIE'S OFFICE — DAY Howie is trying to work. Rick pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I just scored Yankee tickets offa Rowan. Tonight. You interested?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (really considers it) I can’t. I have Group.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You can't skip one night? They're behind home plate.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Another time.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: If there is one. Rick takes off.  35. INT. MEETING HALL — COMMUNITY CENTER — NIGHT Howie stands by himself with a cup of coffee, looking mor out of place than usual. Gabby and Kevin approach.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Going stag tonight?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. Howie sips his coffee. Gabby obviously wants more info.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Becca's gonna...take a little break. From the group. No need to say more that. Gabby smiles sympathetically. Kevin actually looks envious - lucky Becca.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get a coffee. (heads off)

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: (to Howie) Wanna sit?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. INT. NAT'S LIVING ROOM —- NIGHT Nat is on the couch watching television when her phone ri She reaches under some newspapers and answers it.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hey Mom, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  36.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I was just...thinking about making Izzy's birthday cake. Would that be alright?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Oh Honey, you don't need to do all that. I was just gonna grab her one of those Carvel things. She likes those.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (makes a face) I don't mind. It'll give me something to do.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Okay then. Becca checks the fridge to make sure she has everything s needs.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: No group tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie's there. It's too much God talk for me, so... (silence on the other end) What.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s just...some people find that comforting.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You know, Becca, when your brother died, I found the church very helpful.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I know you did, but that's you, not me. And Danny isn’t Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you don’t believe in god anyway. I brought you to church every Sunday--  37.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Let’s not start this again, okay mom? I was just calling about the cake--

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You’re not right about everything, you know. What if there is a God?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Then I’d say he's a sadistic prick.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Alright, Becca. That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: "Worship me and I'll treat you like shit." No wonder you like him, he sounds just like Dad. It’s like a slap. Nat covers the mouthpiece with her hand Becca immediately regrets it. Where did that come from?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Nat takes a breath, then removes her hand from the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You're gonna do the cake then?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Right, I'll see you tomorrow. Nat hangs up abruptly. INT. HOWIE'S CAR — GOING TO THE PARTY - A LITTLE LATER

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Who has a birthday party at a bowling alley anyway? Izzy thinks she's still fourteen.  38.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: If you're not up to this we don’t have to go--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, it’s just a party. I’1l be fine. Becca checks the back seat. A cakebox is carefully placed there. She also notices Danny’s booster seat and gets a little pang.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I really wish you’d take that out of here, Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You’re hardly in this car, what's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It’s just weird. They drive in silence. Howie’s trying to get up the nerve broach a topic. Alright, here goes...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What if we give it another try? (off her silence) Another baby? Becca turns to him, expressionless. Cars fly by outside.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well we're not getting any younger. So if we're thinking about it--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Is that what the sex thing was about the other night?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You trying to get me pregnant?  39.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Becca, no, of course not. I know it's scary, but maybe it might...help us get us back on track.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: On track?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What, we can’t talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I think we should sell the house. (off his blank look) I've been thinking about it, and since we're on the topic--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: How were we on the topic?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’ve talked to a realtor and she thinks we can pull together an open house pretty quickly--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean you talked to a realtor?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We'd probably take a loss in this market but--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Why would you talk to a realtor without telling me?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’m telling you now. Howie is confused and put out by this information.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You want to get us back on track, I think it'd help if we moved.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: We love that house.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: He's everywhere, Howie. The puzzles, the fingerprints on the door jambs--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (taking eyes off the road) I like seeing his fingerprints--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That’s because you don’t have to sit and stare at them all day. You get to go to work. You get to escape!

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to move!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: And I don’t want another baby! Becca looks through the windshield...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (gasps)

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Jesus! Directly ahead of them a car has stopped at a light. Howi slams on the brakes. They are pitched forward. The tires lock and screech. Becca clutches the dashboard her eyes closed. The car comes to a stop behind the car with a couple of f to spare. Silence. Becca opens her eyes, and nods. She takes a deep breath. Then...she leans over into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What do you think I’m doing? I’m checking the cake. It’s fine. And she does. Howie’s jaw tightens, and he restarts the c  41. INT. BOWLING ALLEY —- DAY This place is a dive, but everyone's having fun. Becca's cake has been sliced up and handed out. REEMA and several Izzy's other FRIENDS take turns bowling and drinking beer Becca, trying hard to be chipper, is the official score- keeper. Auggie and Nat are in the midst of a heated but g natured argument. Nat, tipsy, keeps filling a cup with wi

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? The Kennedys? With the assassinations...the lobotomy...?!

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that’s not a curse though. That's just bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: The plane crashes?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Too much money, that's their curse. If those Kennedys lived like normal people, most of them would still be alive.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I think it’s sad.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Of course it’s sad. All those good- looking people falling out of the sky like that. It’s a friggin’ waste.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (whispers to Izzy) Didn't I say no wine?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: She brought it herself.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Isn't this nice? Sitting around talking politics? I never do this. It’s a nice change.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Let’s do gifts.  42.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Yes! Pass ‘em! Becca grabs a big present and hands it over to Izzy.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s heavy.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It’s so pretty. I hate to rip it open. But she does. Izzy unwraps a tasteful bathroom set. Beat. People respond politely. Auggie looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It's a bathroom set.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It's more of a practical gift.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Is this your way of telling me you don't like my Three Stooges shower curtain?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I didn't know what to get you.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Seriously, this is great.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Say thank you.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Becca. Thank you, Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (chuckles a little) Don't thank me, Becca picked it out. (off Becca's look) What?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Okay, now me. Nat hands a gift to Izzy...

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I know it’s a little early but--  43. Izzy unwraps maternity clothes. Much warmer response.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! So sweet. Thank you, Mommy . Izzy hugs her mom. Becca looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I thought we weren't doing baby stuff. For the birthday. (off their looks) I thought we'd wait for the shower.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: No honey, it's not baby stuff, it's mommy stuff.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (xe: towels and such) This is perfect, Bec. I needed a bathroom set.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you need baby stuff more.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: We can take it back.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's right, we should. I'll get you a basket of Mustela lotions. They prevent stretch marks... Becca tries to take the gift back.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Becca, let go. You can get me the lotions another time. They struggle over it. Becca finally lets go.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Silence. Becca is embarrassed. This is awkward. Becca regains her composure and hands Izzy another present.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME — LATER THAT NIGHT Things are much rowdier. Izzy's friends bowl like drunken fools. Becca and Howie with Nat, who’s pretty sloshed.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Oh, I just remembered what I was gonna say about Aristotle Onassis! It was about the son who died in the plane crash! Becca looks at her watch. People bowl.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (to Howie) You ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You should’ve stopped me from going off on that Kennedy stuff, because my point was about Onassis and how he put up a reward to anyone who could prove that someone had sabotaged his son’s plane. He was so desperate to blame somebody. (to Howie) Did you read this? Howie gets up to leave, but Nat keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: He needed a reason for losing his son.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Mom, why are you telling this story?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I'm just talking. I can't talk?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You never just talk. Becca and Howie gather up their coats and things. Izzy co over to say goodbye. Izzy, sensing the danger, tries to defuse the ticking bomb.  45.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Thank you guys for coming to my party. Becca the cake was so good.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You forget what I went through when your brother died. You think I don't know anything, but I do Becca!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Like who to blame? Things are getting tense now. Izzy's friends notice.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You guys, this is my party.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: (takes her hand) Let em’ go. That’s not on you.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about blame, I'm talking about comfort.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Ohhh, comfort. Well then.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Where are you getting it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Comfort? I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Well I think you should.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll get right on that then. See what I can dig up on eBay.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to help you, Becca. I wish someone had given me a little advice when Arthur died. Becca turns on her mother and lashes out...  46.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You know what I wish? I wish you would stop comparing Danny to Arthur! Danny was a four-year-old boy who chased his dog into the street! Arthur was a thirty-year- old heroin addict who OD’d! Frankly I resent how you keep lumping them together! Nothing but the sound of jukebox music and falling pins.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: He was still my son. Becca gathers up her things. Howie, looking deeply uncomfortable, helps to usher her out.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We’re gonna go. Izzy, I hope you enjoy the bathroom set.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna. Becca and Howie head out. No one else moves.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: When Arthur died, I was just as upset as she was, but I never took it out on other people.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What about Mrs. Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Nobody's talking about Mrs. Bailey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca and Howie drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: A_BLANK PIECE OF BLACK PAPER
dialogues.text: The hand appears over a black piece of paper with cutouts intersecting tunnels. The hand paints three faces in a wh portal opening. First a woman, then a man, then a boy. He does this several more times in other portals, varying three faces - sometimes all three, sometimes just one or and sometimes none at all.  47. INT. HOWIE AND BECCA’S BEDROOM — THE NEXT MORNING Becca is at her mirror. She adjusts the blouse she’s wearing. It’s cheery. Classy but cheery.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, did you call that guy about the roof?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I couldn’t find the number.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s in my phone. It’s on the mantle. Becca moves to the phone and picks it up. Howie comes in their bathroom, buttoning up his shirt. Becca seems to be having some trouble with the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It’s not under his name.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (pressing buttons) Then how am I supposed to call him if I--?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It’s under Roof Guy.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (a little chuckle) Roof Guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well what was I supposed to put it under. Becca looks for the number but has trouble with the touch screen on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to use this thing. It doesn’t-- Howie looks over her shoulder, and tries to help...  48.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (gently) Okay, now scroll down.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (she tries to) Now what?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Scroll down with your finger.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You do it. Howie reaches over and finds the number on the phone for

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Roof guy.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Thank you. It's just a small tender marital moment. And then Howie g back to getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is back in her spot, only this time she’s standing the sidewalk next to her car, waiting nervously. She’s wearing her cheery top. Finally the bus pulls up the hill. Becca fixes her hair a little. She waits with anticipation. The bus stops and lets out...the 14-year-old Girl. No Jas Becca is confused and disappointed. She’s about to get ba in her car when...

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you waiting for me? Becca turns to see Jason standing on the sidewalk behind She's obviously taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Um, hi. Yeah, I...I'm sorry, I thought you took the bus.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Right. But not...?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Not today, no. Today I skipped school.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Well... (tries to make a joke) ---you shouldn't be playing hooky, young man. A little nervous laugh from her. Lame.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Why are you waiting for me?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I thought we could talk?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (beat) About what? But she doesn’t respond. Jason isn’t sure what to make of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Becca sit on a park bench. Way off in the dista children play on a jungle gym.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Is this okay?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It's not too weird?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Um, no. I mean...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, I know. It’s weird for me too. Becca tries to smile. Now what?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Don’t you like school?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I like it alright.  50.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. I just thought, you seem to not be going so--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I’ve been accepted to college already, so...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. So it’s not a big deal then.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, it is a big deal, but...only if my mother finds out.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She said she’d confiscate my phone if I did it again. (beat ) Not that I use the phone anyway. Jason nervously picks at the wood of the bench.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Where are you headed?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Connecticut College.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's a good school. And not too far. Your parents must be happy.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's just my mom, but yeah, she's pretty happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She keeps saying she's gonna apply to the grad program so she can keep an eye on me while I'm up there. (beat ) She's just joking though. Becca nods politely.  51.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She's not really looking forward to it, since I'm the only one at home now, but I told her I'd come back on the weekends if I could.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That'll be nice. More silence. Jason looks over at the kids playing.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (simply) So, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (surprised by the topic) Oh, I know, you don't have to--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I know that doesn't help, but...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No it does. It really does.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: And I know I should've tried to get in touch--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I just really wish I had driven down a different block that day.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) I know. Jason hasn't looked at her during this exchange.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You know what? I should maybe go.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: My mom’s gonna start to wonder where I’m at--  52.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's okay. You really don’t have to-- Jason gets up to go. Becca is a little confused by his abruptness. Then Jason stops, and he faces her.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Could we do this again sometime?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) Sure. Jason nods, and takes off, leaving Becca alone on the ben

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie gets out of his car and starts to walk toward the building where Group is held. Only something slows his st At the other end of the parking lot he sees a car idling. Gabby is sitting in the driver’s seat. Just sitting there Something isn’t right. Howie walks towards her, concerned As he comes around the passenger’s side, and looks in the open window, everything becomes clear. Gabby is firing up bowl. She takes a huge toke, and only then sees Howie.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! She tosses the bowl in the ashtray. Howie is really amuse

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Gabby.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you just saw me do that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to sneak up on you. I thought something was wrong. But obviously everything...smells fine.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: You can smell it huh? (laughing and waving smoke outside) God, everyone in there is gonna know. I swear I never do this.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Where’s Kevin?

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: He’s not coming to group. And I blame your wife by the way. I think she put the idea in his head.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well, he didn’t seem to really like group all that much.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: He’s gotten me all upset. I mean, look at me. Smoking pot ina parking lot. It’s like I’m in high school. I’m ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Do you have any more? Gabby chuckles. Then...she realizes he’s serious. And How smiles like a naughty child.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Come on in, partner! INT. MEETING HALL —- COMMUNITY CENTER - NIGHT The support group is well underway. Howie and Gabby sit i the circle of chairs. They are both pretty stoned. Anothe grieving couple speaks...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well if today is rage day, most of you know that I am a little more comfortable with rage. Talking about rage. I deal with rage every single day. And I listen to these guys at work, and they go on and on about paving their driveways, or whatever, just the most stupid nonsense. They don’t know. They haven't had their lives ripped apart yet. Howie starts to snicker quietly. Gabby dare not look at h She is biting the insides of her cheeks so as not to laug

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They’re not in the club.  54.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Exactly. Meanwhile, I’m sitting there like, “Hey guys, my daughter died of leukemia--!"” A burst of laughter escapes from Howie. A few people turn him. He clears his throat and stands.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I need some water. He gets up. Gabby closes her eyes, again so as not to lau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting has let out. Howie and Gabby walk out togethe

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You’re one of those bad kids my mother warned me about.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Yes, I am corrupting you. (re: the pot) Don’t worry, I won’t tell Becca.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (beat) I'd appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Good night. They part ways, heading off to their respective cars. INT. LIVING ROOM —- LATER THAT NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie plunks down into his chair and whips out his I-Phon still stoned. He clicks through his applications looking something. He can’t find it. Howie is confused. He clicks the screen of his phone repeatedly, panic start set in. He scrolls through. Something is very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is reading the Parallel Universes book when she hea Howie yelling.  55.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Becca?! What'd you do here?!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What? We stay on Becca as she dashes from the bedroom, down the stairs, and toward the living room, everything reeling. INT. LIVING ROOM — CONTINUOUS Howie stands in the middle of the room scrolling through I-Phone applications. He's beside himself. Becca stands i the doorway, scared.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, what did you do to my phone?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Jesus, Howie. I thought something had hap--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: This morning. When you used it. What did you do to my phone?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just got the number for the roof guy.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: For christsake!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What, you told me to call him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You deleted Danny's video.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) No, no I didn't. No. I just...you were right there. I just got the number.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you kept pressing the screen.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Because I couldn't figure out how to use your phone.  56. She takes the phone from him and scrolls the screens, try to find it.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I checked already. It's gone.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (still tapping the screen) We have a hundred videos of him, Howie.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: That's not the point, Becca.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Then you should've put it on your computer.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Right, it's my fault.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (still searching) I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I said it's gone! He grabs the phone and hurls it onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Jesus, Howie! I didn't do it on purpose!

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Becca stands staring at him, dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What does that mean? (no response) You think I deliberately deleted his video?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You don't know? She glares, shaken, waiting for some kind of explanation.  57.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It’s like you're trying to get rid of him. I'm sorry, but that's how it feels. Every day, it's something new.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat - holds it together) Really.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s like you're trying to get rid of any evidence he was ever here. You took his paintings off the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yes, to save them. They are ina box downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: His clothes?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We don’t need all that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Your wanting to sell the house. Your sending Taz to your mother's.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: There was a lot going on, Howie. The dog got under foot.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Right. And he was a reminder.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yes, he was a reminder, and I wanted one less reminder around here.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: And since you never wanted the dog.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh, for godssake.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Well if I hadn't bought the dog--  58.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: And if I hadn't run in to get the phone or if I had latched the gate--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I left the gate unlatched!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well I didn’t check it! I’m not playing this game again Howie. It was no one’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Not even the dog's. Dogs chase squirrels, boys chase dogs.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: He loved that dog! And you got rid of it!

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Just like I got rid of the video.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (losing it) It's not just the video! I'm not talking about the video, Becca! It's Taz, and the paintings, and the clothes, and it's everything! You have to stop erasing him! You have to stop it! YOU HAVE TO STOP! Howie's been reduced to tears. He has to move away from h Becca takes him in. She seems more confused than affronte

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Do you really not know how impossible that would be? To erase him? No matter how many things I box up, do you really think I don't see him every second of every day? Howie looks up at her.  59.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: The video was an accident, Howie. And believe me, I’ll beat myself up about it forever, I'm sure. Just like everything else that I could've prevented.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: That's not what I want, Becca.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No? Because it feels like it is. It feels like maybe I don't feel badly enough for you. They stand there, unable to go any further with this.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: This isn't... Something has to change here. Because I can't do this...like this. It's too hard. It's too hard. Howie heads for the door, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: And I want that dog back. Your mother's making him fat.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I miss the dog. I'm sorry, but I miss him. I want him back. They regard each other silently. Howie heads down the hal and then up the stairs, leaving Becca alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is in a secluded corner, working on his comic book. In one panel we see the boy passing through the portal in science lab. And in the next panel we see him falling through a rabbit hole in space. The boy looks terrified. Jason looks up at the clock. Crap, he’s late. He gathers his stuff, and runs.  60. EXT. PARK — DAY Jason sits eating a lemon square. Becca is beside him. There’s a tin of lemon squares between them.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You really made these?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: They're good. Still warm.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like them. They're still pretty formal with each other.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So I've been reading that book. The parallel universe book?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah? Did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s interesting. I don’t know if I buy it - the whole alternate reality thing - I don’t know. But it’s interesting. Did you have to do it for a school project?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No. It's research.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Research. He considers her, then reaches for his backpack. He unzip it, and pulls out a handful of papers held together by a binder clip. He hands the pages to her. Becca looks down at what is obviously the hand-drawn comi book we've seen. The cover is very retro and Flash Gordon esque. Becca reads the title - “Rabbit Hole.”  61.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's a comic book. She flips through the pages - more incredible pen and ink drawings: a strange space portal, science fiction action sequences, a pirate sequence, dinosaurs...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Wow, this is...impressive. You did all this?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Wow. It’s amazing. What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: A scientist, I guess. And his son. The father discovers this network of holes that leads to other galaxies and, um--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Parallel universes.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the scientist dies. So the son goes into this rabbit hole to try and find him. But it’s not him, because he's dead, so it’s like another version of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is looking down at one panel of the comic book: it’ one we saw earlier: the father and son playing ball on th front lawn, the mother with lemonade, and the boy behind tree with the “?!" thought bubble over his head.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I know it's kinda stupid, but...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Not at all. I would love to read it.  62.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (gets uncomfortable) Yeah it’s um... He reaches out and politely takes it back from her, then returns it to his backpack. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Sorry. It’s just... it’s not done yet. But when it is done, I will let you read it.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I don't want you to feel uncomfortable. I--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (interrupts her) I might've been going too fast. (beat) That day. Becca doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, but I might’ve been. So...that's something I've been wanting to tell you. She just sits there and listens. Jason's confession is simple and quiet. There's nothing overwrought about it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's a thirty zone. And I might've been going thirty-one. Or thirty- two. I would usually look down, to check, and if I was a little over, then I'd slow down obviously. But I don't remember checking on your block, so it's possible I was going too fast. And then the dog ran out really fast, so I swerved. I didn’t know... I didn’t know. A moment between them.  63.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I thought you should know. I might've been going a little over the limit. I can't be positive. Becca feels many things. But mostly she feels badly for h

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I know, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. GABBY'S CAR — COMMUNITY CENTER PARKING LOT - NIGHT Gabby and Howie are sitting getting stoned again. They sm up in silence for several beats before anyone speaks.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don't wanna go in there. Gabby looks to him. What are they gonna do instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabby and Howie are at adjacent lanes playing skee-ball. They're having a great time. Gabby bowls an impossible sh

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on!

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, you suck...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I'd be doing better but your pot messed up my depth perception. Howie makes a fairly good shot.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna support that one. I’m totally gonna support that one. She laughs. They continue to play over the following...  64.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Hey you know what. I have a confession to make. Remember when I said Kevin left Group?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: What I meant to say...is that he left me. He left me. Howie continues to bowl, not really sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I came home and he was gone.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Wow. No note or--

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Oh there was a note. Well, nota note so much as a manifesto. On all the ways that we were destroying each other.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
