dialogues.text: Jesus. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Well...this is generally how it goes, right? It changes you. It literally changes people. Part of me thinks it was inevitable. This suddenly feels dangerous. They skee-ball in silence.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I love my wife.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: (pause) Of course you do.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I love her very much.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Okay.  65. INT. LIVING ROOM — HOWIE AND BECCA'S HOUSE — LATER THAT N

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is on the couch reading the Parallel Universe book, when she hears Howie come in the front door. She immediat tucks the book behind a couch cushion, and grabs a magazi INT. FOYER — CONTINUOUS Howie hangs his keys by the door. Then, seeing the living room light on, he feels a pang of guilt. INT. LIVING ROOM — CONTINUOUS Howie stands in the archway for a couple beats before Bec looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So I think you're right. We should maybe look into selling the house. It's probably for the best. Becca barely responds. Why the sudden change in opinion?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. She watches as Howie turns and heads upstairs. INT. DANNY'S ROOM —- A COUPLE WEEKS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat is helping Becca clean out Danny's room. Becca is putting Danny's books into a milk crate. Nat is taking to stuffed animals, puzzles, etc., out of a toy box and plac them into a garbage bag, or into a keep-box. Something stops Nat. She's pulled one of Danny's sneakers out of the toy box. It's smaller than she remembers. Becc glances over at her and realizes what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Don't do that. (takes the sneaker) Quick and clean, like a band-aid. Or we'll never get through this. Becca places the sneaker into a garbage bag, passes Nat a Kleenex, and carries on as if the moment never happened. Nat grabs a couple toys, accidentally flipping the switch an obnoxiously loud flashing toy.  66.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I don't know how to turn it off. It takes a moment, but Becca switches off the toy.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Only people without children give gifts like this. She pops it into the keep-box with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Have you heard from Debbie yet?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: That's too bad. But it can be worse the other way, you know. I remember when Arthur died-- (stops herself) Sorry. Nat bites her tongue and moves away. Becca feels badly.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You can say his name.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Can I? I don't know your rules, Becca. I don't wanna get scolded again.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You can talk about Arthur. I just don't like the comparisons.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay. A moment passes between them. Over the following, they continue to organize the toys...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly) So how is it worse?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You remember Maureen Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah.  67.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I couldn't get rid of her after your brother passed away. She was always at the house.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember that.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Yeah well, I never had a moment to myself. So finally in the middle of coffee one afternoon, I said, "Maureen, why are you always here?"

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: She said, "I wanna be there, Nat, I wanna share in your grief." And so I said "Well it's not working. You plant your fat ass in that chair every frickin' day--"

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You did not say that.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I did! "And you suck up all my coffee, and I don't see you leaving with any of this grief you're allegedly sharing with me. In fact the only thing you do take outta here are my cinnamon buns." (beat ) So I never saw her again obviously. Nat shrugs. She gets a genuine chuckle out of Becca.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I feel guilty now.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You do not.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (laughing) I do. (then) You’re right, I don’t. I don’t miss her at all.  68. EXT. BECCA’s HOME — DAY It is a bright sunny day. Becca’s home has an “open house sign in front of it. EXT. BECCA’S BACKYARD — SAME DAY Taz is back. Howie puts him on a runner in the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca pulls a warm pie out of the oven. It looks perfect. She moves it to the counter. Howie enters through the back door carrying Taz’s leash.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: That takes care of Taz. (eyes the pie) Ah, the ol' apple pie trick, eh?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: For the Open House. Warm baked goods makes it feel homier. I thought you were doing it for the Open House.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. No, I was just making a pie. Howie shrugs - wrong again. Becca tidies up.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So, you’re not gonna stay?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: God, no. You shouldn't either. (off his chuckle) You shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Come on, I'm not gonna bother anyone.  69. INT. FOYER — LATER THAT MORNING Howie is chatting with the slightly uptight middle-aged realtor woman, RHONDA. Becca's getting ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So we have the garbage cans in the back, the sign out front. I mowed the lawn. I thought we’d set the sign-in sheet here, and they could move into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: My wife's gonna go hide out, but I'll stick around, if that's okay with you. Rhonda pauses slightly.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Sure. However you want to do it. Becca heads out.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Bye. (back to Rhonda) I think that’s everything. EXT. PARK —- A LITTLE LATER Becca sits reading the parallel universe book on the same bench she sat with Jason. She didn't make plans with him, but half-hopes she might see him here. She puts down the book and looks around. There are parents minding their kids on the jungle gym. There's a couple sitting on the grass, sharing a newspape A group of guys play touch-football. Only Becca is by herself, and she feels it maybe harder than she ever has.  70. INT. HOWIE AND BECCA'S FOYER —- DAY Howie stands expectantly with a clipboard as a suburban couple (CRAIG and DONNA) with a four year old son, CADEN, come in from the living room with Rhonda.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Southwestern exposures. Sun all day.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: The layout is exactly what we've been looking for.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: (to Donna) And the light in here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I know, it's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Why don’t we take a look upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: That's a great idea. I’11 show you. Follow me. He takes over, leading them upstairs. Rhonda is peeved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie is leading the family past the doorway...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: We can start in the master bedroom if you want to see-- But the wife stops and ducks into Danny’s room.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What’s in here?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s, uh-- The family enters the room. Howie follows them in. Rhonda appears in the doorway, concerned as to how this might go

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: This could be a good room for the little guy, obviously.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How about that, buddy? You like this room? The boy makes a b-line for one of Danny's wind-up robots. Howie is immediately on edge.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Oo, careful with that.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's not yours, honey. The boy reluctantly puts the toy down.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How old's your son? (off Howie's blank look) This is your son's room, I assume?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. I mean...it was, but..-he died. Rhonda lowers her eyes. This is not the thing to say. The couple looks confused. This is suddenly very awkward.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a car. Right out front.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: This must be so difficult for you.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's pretty weird. I still forget he's not here sometimes. Like maybe he's just hiding under the bed or something, and he's gonna pop out. That’s what he used to do. (looks around) I still feel him here. This comes out weirder than Howie intends. The parents ar little creeped out. The little boy looks to the bed.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (beat) Would you like to see the master bedroom? INT. IZZY'S BATHROOM —- MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Izzy, toothbrush in hand, is just finishing a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (on phone) Yeah, I'll be there. She hangs up her cell phone. Auggie pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: AUGGIE
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Becca. She wants to “hang out.” Auggie looks as confused as Izzy. She grabs one of her ne hand towels (from Becca's bathroom set) and wipes her mou The newly decorated bathroom looks fantastic. INT. UPSCALE NAIL SALON — DAY Izzy and Becca sit side by side getting pedicures. Becca flips through a magazine. The PEDICURISTS work in silence

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: This was a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Nice, right? Becca glances over at Izzy's belly.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You're starting to show so early.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I know. I feel like a big ole balloon. I swear, once this kid is born I’m going right to the gym.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: While Mom watches the baby. Becca smiles and goes back to her magazine. Izzy can't qu tell if she's just been insulted.  73.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What does that mean? “While Mom watches the baby.”

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: While you're at the gym, Mom can watch the baby. She loves that.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: No, Auggie can watch the baby. He works nights, so he'll be home.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. Auggie, then. Becca passes her a magazine. Izzy is fighting to bite her tongue, but it’s a losing the battle.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: If you’re gonna be mean to me, then I might as well stay home.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What’d I say?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You think I'm not cut out to be a good mother.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That is not what I think.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I know I'm not as organized as you are, or homey, or whatever--

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Nobody's comparing us.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Really? Because that'd be a first.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Honestly, Izzy, I don't know what this is about.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: It's about me being a capable person who can raise a child, and look after it and protect it. It’s not Izzy’s intention but this wounds Becca.  74.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I resent the feeling I get from you that I don't deserve the baby. Or that I'm not mature enough, or smart enough or something, to take care of it. I mean, my god, if Mom could do it, how hard could it be? Silence. They stare at each other. Then Becca goes back t her reading. INT. SUPERMARKET — DAY Becca and Izzy stroll along with the shopping cart. Muzak

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: This alright?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I’ve just gotta pick up a few things and then we can do lunch. Becca makes her way past walls of sugared kids’ cereals w colorful boxes. She rolls past, not daring to look at the

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER AISLE
dialogues.text: Becca notices a mother, LORI, at the end of the aisle. Sh is shopping with her little boy, SAMMY, in the cart. He's about five, and really not happy.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Please can I have some Fruit Roll- Ups?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: No, Sammy, you know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Please? Can I have some, please?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Sammy. No. Lori very deliberately turns her back on the boy and scan the shelf in front of her, ignoring him entirely, which o angers him more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the Fruit Roll-ups.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Not happening.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Please, I’1ll be good.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: No, I’m not gonna get ‘em. Becca tries to not pay attention, but it gets under The boy's whines turn into wails, and still the mom nothing. It goes on for several beats, until Becca take it anymore. She is suddenly striding down the toward them. Surprised, Izzy hurries after her... But it's too late, Becca is already talking to Lori.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You know what? It's only three bucks, why don't you just get him the roll-ups? The boy stops whining. He and Izzy look to Lori to response. The woman’s eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Not that it's any of your business, but we don't allow candy in our house, and my son knows that.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Come on, it’s just fruit. Why don’t you give him a treat? 75. her skin. does can’t aisle see her  76.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Are you a mom? The question hangs there. Izzy lowers her eyes. Becca is obviously caught off-guard. She struggles to respond.

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I didn’t think so. (moves her cart) Excuse me... Becca suddenly reaches up and smacks her across the face. Hard. The woman stares at her, shocked. Becca and Izzy lo equally shocked. Did that really just happen? The boy looks as if he’s been hit too.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Go to the car, Becca. She doesn't move. Izzy hisses through gritted teeth...

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I said go to the car. Becca, slightly dazed, steps away from them. Everything around her swirls a bit as she breaks into a run and dash for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: (explains to Lori) She just lost her son eight months ago and she’s--

dialogues.speaker: LORI
dialogues.text: I don’t care. INT. BECCA'S CAR — PARKING LOT - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca and Izzy sit in the car, still shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie is looking over the sign-in sheet. Taz is barking o in the yard. Becca and Izzy come in with the grocery bags Becca unpacks the groceries over the following...  77.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So? Fun day out? Becca tosses Izzy a warning glance.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: How'd it go here?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Not so good. We need to clean out that room.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (pause) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Maybe make it into a guest room or something. (to Izzy) Don't get any ideas.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Ha-ha. Then Izzy's smiles disappears. She looks scared. Becca notices and turns around - what's wrong? Howie turns too. And then we see... Jason is standing in the doorway of the kitchen. He's somehow walked in unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hello. Hi...um...The door was wide open so... (no response) And I knocked, but... They all stand there, still taken aback by the moment. Ta is still barking.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Taz! Shut up! Taz stops barking. They all stare at Jason.  78.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I saw the sign outside...the Open House sign, so I thought it’d be okay to--

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You looking to buy a house?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (turns to Becca) I just came to give you this. Jason holds out the "Rabbit Hole" comic book to Becca.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I said I'd let you read it when it was done, so... Becca stands motionless. There's no way out of this. She finally reaches out and takes the book.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Howie looks from Becca to the boy, completely dumbstruck. Izzy is wide-eyed with curiosity. Becca can't even look a Howie. Jason starts to realize what he's done.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: What...what is this?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We...bumped into each other, in the library, and we decided to meet.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You decided to meet.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. A couple times. Howie shakes his head. This is getting weirder and weirde

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't realize--  79.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Did you meet here?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, we met in the park.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: You met in the park a couple times.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Howie's breathing becomes shallow. He's trying hard to ke his anger under control. He advances on Jason a little bi

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So my wife agrees to meet you ina public place, and you...what? Apologize?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Okay, you apologize, and then what?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Alright, Howie, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (xe: book) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It’s a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It’s a comic book. A comic book. Izzy looks to her sister like, what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Did she tell you to bring it here?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie--

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, she didn't.  80.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: No, she didn't. Because this is our house. And just because there's a sign out front doesn't mean you can pop in.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Howie, all right.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: No it’s not alright. You don't just walk into someone's home like that. You should show a little fucking respect. Jason looks to Becca, then makes a quick exit. They're all silent for a couple beats.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're an asshole. She goes out after Jason. Howie watches her go. Izzy puts groceries away.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (whispers to himself) I’m an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie, still rattled, is walking Taz on a leash. The big, dumb dog is essentially pulling him down the block.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Easy... He tugs on the leash, but Taz pays no mind. The dog continues to pant and pull, excited to be out of the yard Again, Howie snaps the leash hard, but it hardly does anything. Howie is getting pissed.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Taz, stop it. Taz suddenly sees/hears some small animal in the hedged-i property next to the sidewalk. He leaps towards the hedge barking ferociously.  81.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Taz. Taz, stop it! Howie snaps the leash back way too hard, and Taz lets out pained YELP! The dog retreats from the hedges, and cowers Howie immediately feels horribly, and runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Oh, buddy... He buries his face in the dog's fur. He feels to make sur he's okay. Howie rubs his neck and pats his fur. Taz look up tentative, and licks Howie's hand. The dog's fine. But Howie feels like a complete and utter heel. INT. BECCA AND HOWIE'S KITCHEN — EVENING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is rolling out dough for a pie crust. Howie appears the doorway. He stands and watches for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me? She stops and looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (simply) For the same reason you don’t tell me why you come home reeking of pot. Howie takes this in. Then retreats quietly from the doorw Becca goes back to rolling her pie crust. INT. GARAGE — DAY Becca and Nat carry the milk crates of Danny's stuff down the basement, and put them in the corner with a few other things Becca has put aside. Becca stands there, taking it in. Danny's been reduced to small corner of stuff in the basement. She lets out a breath, then turns to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Does it ever go away?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: What.  82.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: This feeling. They lock eyes. Nat can see she actually wants an answer. Maybe for the first time ever.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: No. I don't think it does. Not for me it hasn't. And that's goin' on eleven years. (beat) It changes though.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I don't know. The weight of it, I guess. At some point it becomes bearable. It turns into something you can crawl out from under, and carry around - like a brick in your pocket. And you forget it every once in a while, but then you reach in for whatever reason and there it is: "Oh right. That." Which can be awful. But not all the time. Sometimes it's kinda... Not that you like it exactly, but it's what you have instead of your son, so you don't wanna let go of it either. So you carry it around. And it doesn't go away, which is...

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Fine...actually. They're silent for a couple beats. Becca nods a little. N turns and heads up the basement steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both in bed reading. Becca is engrossed in Jason' comic book. Howie glances over, a bit annoyed by it. We see a panel - the boy in the story is running from an of armor-clad knights.  83. He passes through a portal, and in the next panel he's falling through another rabbit hole. He lands on a suburb block. The thought-bubble over the boy's head reads, "There's my house! I'm back home!" We follow Becca’s eye across the panels. We see the boy a the front door of the house, and the parents staring down him confused. The bubble over the boy’s head reads, “It’s me! Your son!” And the mother’s bubble reads, “But we don have a son.” The next panel: a close-up of the boy’s devastated face. in the next panel, he asks them, “Would you like one?” Becca lets out a little gasp when she sees the picture. Howie looks over, intrigued. But she doesn’t explain.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GABBY'S HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Gabby walks to answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Hello? INT. HOWIE'S OFFICE —- MANHATTAN - INTERCUT PHONE CALL

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Howie. Howie Corbett. From Group? Gabby is obviously taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Hi, Howie. EXT. YARD — LATE AFTERNOON Taz is barking and jumping as Howie makes his way to the house. Howie places the food down, and Taz attacks it. Howie turns back to the house, and sees Becca working in garden. She's looking at him strangely.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hi. You're going to group tonight, right?  84.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (tries to sound off-hand) Yeah. You didn't want to come, did you?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No. Howie tries to not look relieved. Becca looks a little guilty, as if she might have a secret as well.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I'm just gonna hop in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. He gives a little wave, and heads in. Becca watches him g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie, freshly showered and changed, heads for his car. O guilty look over his shoulder, and he gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca watches from behind a curtain as Howie's car pulls away. As soon as it does, she grabs the "Rabbit Hole" com book and her car keys, and heads for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Becca pulls out of the driveway, and drives off in th opposite direction. As they drive down various suburban roads, we intercut between the two cars. Becca and Howie are both nervous, a eager to get where they're going. INT. BECCA’S CAR — DUSK Becca places the comic book up on the dashboard. INT. HOWIE'S CAR — DUSK Howie checks his teeth in the rearview mirror.  85. INT. BECCA'S CAR — INTERCUT Becca is on her cell phone. We hear Jason’s voice on the outgoing message. Becca hangs up before it’s finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie finally reaches his destination. It's a beautiful house on a nice block. He slows to a stop at the curb. He puts the car into park. He looks up at the house, and takes a deep breath. He's terrified. He doesn't move. He just sits in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, he can't bear it anymore. He opens the car door, and gets out. He smooths his shirt, and heads up the walk way toward Gabby's front door. It's just a few yards, but the walk may as well be a hundred miles. The door opens, and Gabby steps outside. She looks pretty

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Did you find the house okay? Howie doesn't respond. He doesn't even move.

dialogues.speaker: GABBY
dialogues.text: Howie? Is he going to go through with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls up Jason's block, and can't help smiling. She's grown to enjoy these encounters with him. But as she gets closer, her smile fades. She's really not expecting to see the scene in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca stops the car a safe distance away, unnoticed by anyone. There's a limo parked at the bottom of the drivew Becca watches as Jason, in a tuxedo, very self-consciousl pins a corsage to a SKINNY GIRL in a prom dress.  86. JASON'S MOTHER, giddy with pride, takes picture after picture. JASON'S BUDDY and his BUDDY'S DATE heckle them f inside the car. When it's time to go, Jason and his date, move to squeeze the back seat. Lots of good-natured shoving, and big dres flipping up, and laughing. Jason's mother, laughing herself, captures it all on film INT. BECCA'’S CAR — CONTINUOUS It's a relatively benign scene, but Becca watches it as someone might watch a car-wreck - stunned, confused, a li disbelieving... The limo doors close, and as it's about to drive off... ...something huge and uncontrollable opens up inside of Becca, and she begins to cry. A lot. She clutches the steering wheel and pretty much loses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason, at the wheel of his car, terror in his eyes, turns see Becca standing outside of her house, trembling, not comprehending at all what she sees. They lock eyes. Though Becca has just seen the body of Danny, we never do We only see Becca and Jason in this moment. And then... INT. LIMO — SIMULTANEOUS (SLO-MO Still laughing, Jason turns for just a moment and sees Becca's car as they roll by. Becca is hysterical but sile behind the glass of her windows. Jason's smile disappears

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE LIMO
dialogues.text: Jason watches as Becca and her car disappear behind him, he continues on to his prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie is still standing there. Gabby is waiting. She trie to smile. Howie takes a step back.  87.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (barely a whisper) I'm sorry. Howie turns, and heads for the car. He gets back in. Gabb watches as he starts the car and pulls away. When he's gone, her shoulders drop in defeat. She slips inside, and gently closes the door behind her. INT. HOWIE'S CAR — SPEEDING HOME - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie is suddenly in a big hurry to get home. He flies through the suburban back roads, determined, and terrifie the very big mistake he very nearly made. EXT. HOWIE AND BECCA’S FRONT OF HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie gets out of the car, and yanks the back door open. grabs the booster from the back seat, and tosses it in th bags of garbage that have been put on the curb for pick-u He closes the car door, and heads into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howie tosses his keys by the door, and peeks into the liv room, but there's no one here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sign of Becca. He peers out the kitchen window into th backyard. Taz is asleep in the dog house. He moves to the basement door, and listens. Nothing. He calls down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Becca? Still, nothing. This is odd. Where did she go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs upstairs, a bit of panic creeping in now.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Becca...?  88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ducks his head in. No one there. INT. DANNY'S ROOM —- CONTINUOUS Howie clicks on the light. Of course there's no one here either. He looks around the room. But there's nothing. Other than the stripped bed, the room is completely empty And slowly, we see Howie’s determination drain out of his body. He’s too late. Becca isn’t here. And he’s convinced she’s actually left him. Spent, Howie sits on the bed, staring off into space. The he quietly takes off his shoes, and lies back on the bed. BACK TO BECCA IN HER CAR - STILL ACROSS FROM JASON’S HOUS The prom car is gone. Becca is alone now. The street is empty again. She finally lets go of the steering wheel. Her crying is pretty much over. But she doesn't start the car. She just sits there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Becca is asleep in her car - pretty much where we left he There a little tap-tap-tap at her window. She wakes up, disoriented, and sees Jason outside, still in his tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Almost five?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: And you're just getting home?  89. EXT. PARK — MINUTES LATER They're back on their bench. The sun is creeping over the fields of the park. They've been sitting here for awhile without saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So how was it?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It was okay.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well you look nice.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Was that your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Just a friend.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: She's pretty. Jason looks to "Rabbit Hole" which sits on the bench betw them. Becca smiles, and picks up the comic book.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Well, I liked this so much. It’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It reminded me of Orpheus and Eurydice. Do you know that myth?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Eurydice dies, and Orpheus misses her so much, that he travels to Hades to retrieve her, but in the end it doesn't work out.  90.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I should read it. Becca flips through the book. Jason undoes his bow-tie.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So, is the scientist your dad? (off his blank look) The scientist the boy is looking for, is that your dad?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (beat) No.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I mean, is it based on him?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No. My dad was an English teacher.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. I was curious about that part.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It's just a story.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No, I know. I was just...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Reading into it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. They sit there. A jogger runs by in silence.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Do you think they're real?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Parallel universes?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I think it’s basic science. If space is infinite, then everything is possible.  91. She smiles a little. This was the answer she was hoping f

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So somewhere out there, there's a version of me -- what? -- making pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Or at a water park.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Wherever, yeah. Both. Laws of probability. There are tons of you's out there, and tons of me's.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So this is just the sad version of us.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (beat) I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: But there are other versions where everything goes our way.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Assuming you believe in science.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: (beat) Well that's a nice thought. That somewhere out there I'm having a good time. Jason smiles. They look out over the fields, and the sun peeking through the trees. INT. DANNY'S ROOM — MORNING Howie fell asleep on Danny's bed last night. He wakes up, squinting at the sun coming in from the windows. We hear the clink of mugs being taken from a cabinet, and coffee being made. Morning sounds.  92. It's so strikingly normal that Howie wonders for a moment he isn’t imagining it. And when he realizes he isn’t, a w of relief washes over him. INT. KITCHEN — MOMENTS LATER Becca is at the table, drinking her coffee, nibbling on a piece of pastry. Howie comes in, still sleepy, and takes in the scene. He gets a mug, and pours himself some coffee. Howie gets a plate, and cuts himself a piece. Then moves the table. They drink their coffee. After a while...

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you had left. She sees the fear in his eyes, and she feels badly for hi

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: No. I didn't leave. Howie hides his relief by reaching for the morning paper, leafing through its contents.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So I was thinking we should invite Rick and Debbie over for a cookout. Howie looks up at her, totally perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: She's never gonna call. She thinks I hate her. I might as well just let her off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So a cookout then.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: It'll be good to see the kids. We should get something for Emily though. We missed her birthday. She turned four last week.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Howie stares into his coffee mug.  93.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Danny's is coming up.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: That's gonna be a tough one.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Howie looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: So the kid... Jason. Did you tell him we didn't blame him?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: We don’t blame him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: No, I know, but did you let him know that?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (beat) That's good.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Look, Howie, if you want talk with him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay. They pick at the Danish.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: It's so quiet.  94.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: That's because I slipped Taz a couple Ambien.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) You're funny.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You think I'm joking. A nice moment between them. It’s been awhile since they’v had one. Becca faces him - down to business now.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So what are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I don't know, pick something.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: (thinks it over) Well...We could go to Village Toys tomorrow and pick up Candy Land for Emily. That's probably something she'd like.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Okay, Candy Land. That's a start. Then what?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: Then we wrap it.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE
dialogues.text: And then we have the cookout... Howie's voice continues over the following scenes...  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright day. Howie is at the grill. Nat is blabbing away to him. Becca is chatting with her neighbors (Peg and Pet Rick and Debbie come through the back gate with EMILY, 4 ROBBIE, 7. Becca gets up and welcomes them.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And they'll come over, and we'll have a couple other people so it's not too awkward for anyone. Debbie is still rather sheepish and apologetic when greet Becca. The kids make a b-line for Taz, who's tied up in t doghouse, and happy to see them.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And to make them feel comfortable we'll ask a bunch of questions about what the kids have been up to, and we'll pretend that we're really interested. Howie's voice continues over several more shots from the Izzy, looking especially pregnant, shows up with Auggie. She's brought some kind of pie. Becca seems both shocked impressed by it. Despite the iconic suburban cookout, this should feel mor winsome than happy. The unresolved issues linger.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then we'll wait for someone to bring up Danny while the kids are playing. And maybe that'll go on for a little while. And as he describes, we see them all sitting around havin some adult conversation as the sun goes down. SAME — DUSK Everyone's gone. Howie and Becca are sitting next to each other in separate chairs looking out at the fading light the water. They are both lost in thought. All around them is the wreckage of the cookout.  96.

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And after that they'll go home. Becca glances over at Taz, who is quiet and exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) I don't know. Something though. We'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will we?

dialogues.speaker: HOWIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think so. I think we will. Becca looks to Howie. They both look a bit scared. She reaches over and takes his hand...for the first time very long time. It's a simple gesture - not of resolution - but of possibility. Howie holds on tight. And we... FADE OUT.
